newsitem.title: DENMARK: Danish town transformed before neo-Nazi protest.
newsitem.headline: Danish town transformed before neo-Nazi protest.

text.p: This quiet Danish town was transformed on Saturday as hundreds of police prepared to keep Danish and foreign neo-Nazi groups from clashing with leftist counter-demonstrators.
Roskkilde, west of Copenhagen, resembled a town under siege. Police carrying tear gas guarded all entries to the town, scrutinising vehicles and checking their occupants.
The heaviest concentration of police was around the central railway station where officers told Reuters they feared rival groups arriving by train might clash.
Police said Roskild residents had been warned to stay out of the way on Saturday afternoon because of the possibility of clashes.
The neo-Nazi groups are marching to mark 10 years since the death of Hitler's deputy Rudolf Hess.
A force of 800 officers has streamed into Roskilde to keep up to 400 neo-Nazis and 1,000 of their sworn opponents apart.
"We must hope that both sides behave better than last time but we shall plan for the worst eventuality, that's why we are deploying so many," Roskilde police chief Uffe Kornerup said.

A 1995 march in the town, against the arrest locally of German-American neo-Nazi leader Gary Lauck, turned into a rout when neo-Nazis were scattered by a far larger group of leftists who later stoned the buses taking the right-wingers home.
Jonni Hansen, chairman of the Danish National Socialist Movement (DNSB) says he has no confidence in the police to safeguard his marchers this time.
"We don't trust the police, but we are well-prepared," he told Reuters. He did not give details.
Hansen was warned by police on Saturday that detailed threats against him had been received. The DNSB is secretive about its strength but is believed to number about 200.
Anti-Nazi groups say that local Hess marchers' numbers will be swollen by allied groups from Norway, Sweden and Germany and from Britain.

Denmark's liberal freedom of speech laws have made it something of a neo-Nazi haven, to the irritation of neighbouring Germany, where Nazi tracts and paraphenalia are banned and to the discomfort of Danes who remember wartime Nazi occupation.
German police are also bracing for clashes with neo-Nazi groups throughout the weekend of the Hess anniversary.

Hess hanged himself with an electric cord in Berlin's Spandau prison on August 17, 1987, and the date has become a rallying point for the radical right in Germany and other European countries in recent years.
